title-group.article-title: Optimal vibration control for structural-acoustic coupling system

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Qatar University, Qatar
2Department of Aerospace Engineering, Cairo University, Egypt
3Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, USA

author-notes.corresp: Ashraf Omran, Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, USA Email: aomra001@odu.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This paper proposes designing a static output feedback controller for a structural-acoustics coupling system using piezoelectric actuators. The system consists of a rectangular cavity with two flexible plates, one at the top of the cavity and the other at the bottom, and four other rigid boundaries. Piezoelectric pair patches are considered to be bonded to the top plate, and each pair is assumed to produce a pure moment actuation. The top plate is exposed to an external pressure excitation due to a planar wave generated by a sound source mounted above the cavity. The series solution is assumed for the displacements of the plates and the pressure inside the cavity. The responses of the coupled system are obtained using Galarkin’s method. In the control scheme, the controller gains have been optimally tuned using genetic algorithms. The proposed static output feedback controller shows an acceptable performance with simple implementation requirements compared to the linear quadratic Gaussian state feedback controller.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Control of vibration and noise in air vehicles is a challenging problem in aerospace engineering design. The demands of passengers for a comfortable ride in civil airplanes increase the significance of designing the appropriate controller. The engines in fixed wing airplanes and the rotor in helicopters are the main source of vibration and noise in the aircraft’s passenger cabins (structure-borne noise). The characteristics of structure-acoustic systems for flight applications have a significant dependence on flight conditions over the entire flight envelope. These flight conditions can be defined in terms of flight speed and altitude. Designing a control, which has the capability to keep the system behaving acceptably with regard to any change in operating conditions, is considered a challenging task. Gain scheduling has been effectively applied to similar control problems such as a stability augmentation system (SAS) and a control augmentation system (CAS) and it has been used for other structural applications (Mayuresh and Dewey, 2002). The conceptual framework of gain schedule starts by breaking down the operating domain (flight envelopes) to a set of points. Each point has its own characteristics as functions of the flight conditions. A controller is designed for each point individually. These local controllers are scheduled to build a global one, when interpolation is employed to switch in between. The simplicity of the local control law should be sought in terms of implementation and computation expenses, because, any complicated control law leads to an impractical global one. This reduces the stability and performance robustness for such control.

Linear quadratic regulator (LQR) is one of the most common techniques applied to structural acoustics (Preumont and Seto, 2008). In LQR, state feedback controller is initially computed assuming that all states are measurable. The state feedback control gainsare computed for specific design perspectives such as eigenvalues and/or eigenvectors assignments. Although the technique has the capability to achieve significant improvements in system behavior, the resultant sophisticated architecture of the controller restricts the usage of such a controller for a gain scheduling methodology or sensor/actuator optimal placement. In fact, the number of measurements is always less than the actual number of states. An estimator is then constructed to feed this control law by the estimated states. Such an estimator is a dynamic system with the same order as the system. In this case, the control has an inherent dynamics. Most of the structural acoustic systems have a massive number of states; the number of states could be hundreds or thousands. Consequently, the control law based on LQR with an estimator has the same order, which is virtually impossible to be employed for gain scheduling.

On the other hand, static output feedback (SOF) control is notable by a simple static architecture, while the measured outputs of an array of sensors are passed through a constant gain compensator matrix and back into the system as control forces. Computing this constant gain compensator matrix is considered as an optimization problem by any arbitrary performance index. The theory of an optimal SOF is firstly presented in Smith and Clark (1997). The theory aims to optimally tune a static gain matrix to stabilize the closed-loop system and minimize the quadratic performance given by system inputs and measurements as in the case of LQR. However, unlike the LQR controller, SOF is easy to implement with more suitability for gain scheduling application and sensor/actuator placement. This simplicity brings SOF ahead of line especially for structural systems (Levine and Athans, 1970; Waszak and Srinathkumar, 1995; Yuan et al., 2005; Mayuresh and Dewey, 2002; Wouter et al., 2006), when these systems are described by hundreds of states while the number of actuators or sensors is no more than 10. For example, if the system has an N states vector and M inputs vector and P outputs vector, using LQR delivers a controller with N x N states and M x P transfer matrix which iscomputationally expensive. Instead, SOF offers the controller as M x P static matrix.

In this paper, an optimal SOF is offered for a damping plate’s vibration of a plate-cavity-plate system. The proposed optimal SOF is compared to LQR as a design base. The comparative study is presented to emphasize the ability of SOF to deliver reasonable behavior with less computation and more practical implementation. The organization of the paper proceeds as follows. InSection 2, modeling of sound transmission through a plate-cavity-plate system is presented. In Section 3, a brief discussion for both LQR and SOF is presented to damp the induced plate’s vibration due to external pressure excitation of the upper plate. The optimization technique of SOF is presented in Section 4 using genetic algorithms (GA). In Section 5, SOF is tested for a generic numerical model. The results are compared with LQR control. Finally the conclusions are presented in Section 6.

sec.title: 2. Plate-cavity-plate modeling
sec.p:
The system to be modeled consists of a rectangular cavity with two flexible plates, one at the top of the cavity, the other at the bottom, and four other fixed boundaries. Piezoelectric (PZT) pair patches are considered to be bonded to the top plate (see Figure 1), and each pair is assumed to produce a pure moment actuation when an electric signal is used to excite them. The top plate is exposed to an external pressure excitation due to a planar wave generated by a sound source assumed to be mounted above the cavity. The inner dimensions of the cavity are Lxc, Lyc and Lzc, in thex, y, and z directions respectively, and the effective dimensions of the plate are Lxp and Lyp . As shown in the schematic of the plate-cavity-plate system (see Figure 1), two coordinate systems are used to describe the system; the first one with the origin at Oc is used for the cavity, and the second one with the origin at Op is used for the plates. The plate may have larger dimensions than the cavity. The two plates are set such that one of them isatthe top of the cavity at z=Lzc, while the other is atthe bottom of the cavity at z=0 . Throughout the analysis, the ambient values are indicated with the subscript ( )o . For convenience, the structural-acoustic system modeling is divided into the following subsystems: (i) the plate-cavity-plate system, (ii) the plate-piezo system, and (iii) the piezo-plate-cavity-plate system. Figure 1.
(a) Schematic of the plate-cavity-plate system used for the analysis model (b) Labels and centers’ locations of the actuator pairs on the upper plate.

sec.title: 2.1. The plate-cavity-plate system
sec.p: The two governing equations of this system are the conservation of mass equation and the conservation of momentum equation. In three-dimensional space, making use of linear approximations, the wave equation describing the sound field inside the cavity can be obtained as: (1)∇2P+γc∂P∂t-1co2∂2P∂t2=0 where P(x,y,z;t) is the air pressure inside the cavity, ρ is the medium density and γc is the cavity damping coefficient. The speed of sound in a medium assuming isentropic flow is defined as: (2)c=dPdρ

At a rigid boundary, the normal component of the air particle velocity is set to zero, and at a flexible boundary, it is set equal to the normal velocity of theflexible plate. Thus, the boundary conditions can be stated as: (3)∂P∂n={0-ρo∂2w∂t2 atrigidboundary atflexibleboundary where w(x,y;t) is the normal displacement of the flexible boundary, and n is the direction normal to the boundary. The pressure field inside the cavity can be expressed in the series form (4)P(x,y,z;t)=∑i=1∞Φi(x,y,z)qi(t)=∑i=1∞ψi(x)ϕi(y)Γi(z)qi(t) where Φi(x,y,z) are used to describe the spatial field and qi(t) are used to describe the associated temporal part of the pressure response. The spatial functions ψi(x), ϕi (y) and Γi(z) are assumed to be orthogonal. Substituting equation (4) into equation (1), integrating over the volume of the cavity (Galarkin’s approach (Fletcher, 1984)), and making use of the orthogonality conditions and the boundary conditions, the cavity governing equations can be derived to have the following form (5)1co2∂2qi∂t2+γc∂qi∂t+[ki2-(ΓidΓidz)|ocLzc]qi=0 where (6)da1dτ=12πpr1r2∫02π{bp[-pcos(φ1-θ1)+2r2ζ1sin(φ1-θ1)]+pa1[(p-r1r2)cosφ1-2r2ζ1sinφ1]+qar[cos(φ1+θr-θ1)+2pr1ζ2sin(φ1+θr-θ1)]}sinφ1dφ1 equation (5) will be used later with the plate-piezo equations to satisfy the boundary condition at the flexible plate.

sec.title: 2.2. The piezoelectric actuator-plate system
sec.p: The plate–piezo system is treated here as a multi-laminate system that consists of three plies in places where the piezo pair patches are bonded to the plate, and as a single ply plate otherwise. Making use of the assumptions used in earlier studies (Balachandran et al., 1996; Al-Bassyiouni and Balachandran, 2005), the plate displacement can be described by: (7)D∇4w+ρphpw··+γpw·=pin-pi -∑i=1k(hp-hpzt)Epztd31(1-ν)∇2χiVi(t) where h is the thickness, D is the plate’s stiffness, γp is the plate damping coefficient, E is the modulus of elasticity, ν is the Poisson’s ratio, d31 is the PZT dielectric constant, and Vi is the control voltage applied to the ith PZT patches. The quantity χi is unity where the ith PZT patch pair is present, and zero elsewhere. The plate response is assumed in the series: (8)w(x,y;t)=∑i=1∞αi(x)βi(y)ηi(t) where the ηi(t) are temporal functions and the appropriate expressions for the spatial functions αi(x) and βi(y) are obtained from the work of Blevins (1979). The upper plate only has the PZT patches and the incident pressure waves excite it. Hence, the equations governing the two plates can be written as: (9a)D∇4wU+ρphpw··U+γpw·U=pin-pUi -∑i=1k(hp-hpzt)Epztd31(1-ν)∇2χUiVi(t) (9b)D∇4wL+ρphpw··L++γpw·L=pin where the subscript ( )U and ( )L are used to refer to the upper and lower plates respectively.

sec.title: 2.3. The coupled piezo-plate-cavity-plate system
sec.p: In this section, the plate-cavity system is coupled with the piezoelectric actuator-plate system to obtain the governing equations for the coupled cavity subsystem. The boundary conditions at the flexible boundary are recalled from equation (3): (10a)∂P∂z|z=oc=-ρo∂2wL∂t2 (10a)∂P∂z|z=Lzc=-ρo∂2wU∂t2

Using this boundary condition along with equations (4) and (8), and making use of the orthogonality property, we get the following equation: (11a)∂Γj∂z|z=Lzcqj(t)=-ρo∑i=1∞Bxij(c)Byij(c)η··U(t) (11b)∂Γj∂z|z=0oqj(t)=-ρo∑i=1∞Bxij(c)Byij(c)η··L(t) where (12)da1dτ=12πpr1r2∫02π{bp[-pcos(φ1-θ1)+2r2ζ1sin(φ1-θ1)]+pa1[(p-r1r2)cosφ1-2r2ζ1sinφ1]+qar[cos(φ1+θr-θ1)+2pr1ζ2sin(φ1+θr-θ1)]}sinφ1dφ1

After substituting equation (11) into equations (5) and (6), we get the equation governing a pressure-field mode as follows: (13)1co2q··j(t)+γcq·j(t)+kj2qj(t)-(-ρo∑i=1∞Bxij(c)Byij(c))(Γj|z=Lzcη··U(t)-Γj|z=Lzcη··L(t))=0

The last terms on the left-hand side of equation (13) represent the structural-acoustic coupling in the system. At this stage, it is assumed that the spatial functions in equation (4) are given by rigid-body cavity modes (Blevins, 1979); that is: (14)ψi(x)=AiLxccos(liπxLxc),ϕi(y)=AiLyccos(miπyLyc)Γi(z)=AiLzccos(niπzLzc) where the indices li,mi,andni are associated with the spatial functions of the ith rigid cavity mode, in the x,y,andz directions, respectively. The constants Ai are chosen to satisfy the orthogonality conditions. Using equation (14) the spatial function Γj(z) at each plate will be: (15)g(Γj(z)g)g|atplate=g{g.g(Γj(z)g)g|z=Lzc=(-1)jAjLzcatupperplateg.g(Γj(z)g)g|z=0=AjLzcatlowerplate

Making use of equation (15) in equation (13), it is found that (16)(1co2)q··j(t)+γcq·j(t)+(lj2π2Lxc2+mj2π2Lzc2+nj2π2Lzc2)q(t) +((-1)jAjLzcρo∑i=1∞Bxij(c)Byij(c))η··U(t) -(AjLzcρo∑i=1∞Bxij(c)Byij(c))η··L(t)=0

The equations governing the plate modal amplitudes are obtained by making use of equations (4), (7), (8) and (14). After making use of the orthogonality properties and boundary conditions, the equations governing the modal amplitudes of the plates are obtained as: (17a)ρphpη··Uj(t)+γpη·Uj(t)+D[Ixj+Iyj]ηUj(t) +2D∑i=1∞IxijIyijηUi(t) =∑i=1∞(-1)jAiLzcBxij(p)Byij(p)qi(t)-[∫ApαjβjpUis(x,y)dAp]pit(t) -∑i=1k[∫Apαjβj(hp+hpzt)Epztd31(1-ν)∇2χU(xi,yi)dAp]Vi(t) (17b)ρphpη··Lj(t)+γpη·Lj(t)+D[Ixj+Iyj]ηLj(t) +2D∑i=1∞IxijIyijηLi(t) =∑i=1∞AiLzcBxij(p)Byij(p)qi(t) where the different spatial integrals are given as (18)da1dτ=12πpr1r2∫02π{bp[-pcos(φ1-θ1)+2r2ζ1sin(φ1-θ1)]+pa1[(p-r1r2)cosφ1-2r2ζ1sinφ1]+qar[cos(φ1+θr-θ1)+2pr1ζ2sin(φ1+θr-θ1)]}sinφ1dφ1
In equation (17), the incident pressure loading can be expressed as the product of spatial and time domain functions; that is, (19)pi(x,y;t)=pis(x,y)pit(t)

Equations (16) and (17) can be represented in matrix form, after truncating the infinite number of modes to the first M plate modes and N acoustic modes, as follows: (20)[MppU00McpUMccMcpL00MppL](η··Uq··η··L)+[DppU000Dcc000DppL](η·Uq·η·L) +[KppUKpcU00Kcc00KpcLKppL](ηUqηL)=[FpUFVU0000](pitV)

In these equations {Mpp,Kpp}∈ℜM×M, {Mcc,Kcc}∈ℜN×N, Mcp∈ℜN×M, Kpc∈ℜM×N, Fp∈ℜM×1, and FV∈ℜM×k . The different quantities in the above equation are given by: (21a)MppU=MppL=diag⌊ρphp⌋ (21b)MccU=MccL=diag[1co2] (21c)McpU=ρo[(-1)iAiLzcBxji(c)Byji(c)] (21d)McpL=-ρo[AiLzcBxji(c)Byji(c)] (21e)DppU=DppL=diag⌊γp⌋ (21f)Dcc=diag⌊γc⌋ (21g)KppU=KppL=2D⌊IxjiIyji⌋+Ddiag⌊Ixi+Iyi⌋ (21h)KccU=KccL=diag[lj2π2Lxc2+mj2π2Lzc2+nj2π2Lzc2] (21i)KpcU=[-(-1)jAjLzcBxji(p)Byji(p)] (21j)KpcL=[-AjLzcBxji(p)Byji(p)] (21k)FpU=(-∫ApαiβipUisdAp) (21l)FVU=[-∫Apαiβi(hp+hpzt)Epztd31(1-ν)∇2χU(xj,yj)dAp]

For simplicity, the damping coefficients will be assumed constant during the numerical analysis (γc=γp=0.002). The matrices McpandKpc describe the structural-acoustic coupling, while the matrices Kpp represent the plate stiffness matrix. Equation (20) represents the time-domain model developed for thesystem shown in Figure 1. After determining the modal amplitudes from these equations, the plate displacements w(x,y;t) and the pressure fields inside the cavity p(x,y,z;t) can be obtained from the following relations: (22){wU(x,y;t)p(x,y,z;t)wL(x,y;t)}=[CU(w)(x,y)000C(p)(x,y,z)000CL(w)(x,y)]{ηU(t)q(t)ηL(t)} where (23a)CU(w)=[αi(x)βi(y)] (23b)C(p)=[ψi(x)ϕi(y)Γi(z)] (23c)CL(w)=[αi(x)βi(y)]

sec.title: 3.1. LQR-state estimator design
sec.p: The state space representation for the plate-cavity-plate system given in Section 2 is described as: (24)x·(t)=Ax(t)+Bdd(t)+Buu(t)y(t)=Cx(t) where x∈ℜNx is the state vector, A∈ℜNx×Nx is the system state dynamic matrix, u∈ℜNu is the actuator command vector, Bu∈ℜNx×Nu is the control actuation matrix, d∈ℜNd is the disturbance vector, Bd∈ℜNx×Nd is the disturbance actuation matrix, y∈ℜNy is the sensor measurement vector, C∈ℜNy×Nx is the matrix relating the sensor measurement vector to the state vector. For state feedback control law, the control actuator vector u is linearly related to the state vectorxby: (25)u(t)=-Kxx(t) where Kx∈ℜNu×Nx is the control gain matrix. The control gain matrix Kx is computed based on specific design criteria such as pole placement or assigned eigenvector. Also, optimization is applied to compute the matrix Kx to minimize a cost function J(t,x,u). One of the most widely used methods to design a full state feedback control for linear systems is the optimal LQR. Thus, the cost function J(t,x,u) is defined as: (26)Jg(t,x,ug)=∫0∞g[xTg(τg)Qxg(τg)+uTg(τg)Rug(τg)g]dτ where Q∈ℜNx×Nx is a symmetric positive semi-definite state weighting matrix, and R∈ℜNu×Nu is a symmetric positive definite control effort weighting. Since measuring the states is not possible, estimation is the choice. If the estimate of the state vector is denoted by x∧, then the control law in equation (25) becomes: (27)u(t)=-Kxx∧(t)

One method of estimating the state is to construct a full-order model of the plant dynamics as: (28)∧·x(t)=Ax∧(t)+Bu(t)+L(y(t)-Cx∧(t)) where L∈ℜNx×Ny is the estimator gain matrix to stabilize the dynamics of estimating error defined as: (29)e·(t)=(A-LC)e(t)

To success the estimation process, the estimation dynamics in equation (29) should be faster than the expected dynamics of the system. Combining both system and estimator dynamics, the overall system dynamics in the state form is: (30)[x·e·]=[A-BKBK0A-LC][xe]

sec.title: 3.2. Static output feedback control
sec.p: Unlike the LQR controller, SOF assumes the control law as a linear combination between the measurement vector y and actuation vector u as (31)u(t)=-Kyy(t) where Ky∈ℜNu×Ny is the control gain matrix for SOF. This matrix is computed to stabilize the closed-loop system and minimize the quadratic performance J(t,x,u). By substituting from (31) to (26), the cost function J(t,x,u) is then defined as: (32)J(t,x,u)=∫0∞xT(τ)[ Q+CTKyTRCKy]x(τ)dτ

The cost function J(t,x,u) is bounded, if the system is stable with positive definite matrix Q. The first order condition for this optimization problem is (Mayuresh and Dewey, 2002; Wouter et al., 2006): (33)Ky=-R-1BuTSPCT(CPCT)-1

The matrices P∈ℜNx×Nx and S∈ℜNx×Nx are given by a set of coupled nonlinear matrix equations in terms of system parameters and Ky. Thus, the calculation of Ky involves the solution of three equations including equation (33) for Ky and the Lyapunov equations given as (Mayuresh and Dewey, 2002; Wouter et al., 2006): (34)(A-BuKyC)P+P(A-BuKyC)T+BdBdT=0 (35)(A-BuKyC)TS+S(A-BuKyC)+Q+CTKyTRKyC=0

Equations (33)–(35) are a set of 3xNxN nonlinear equations. Solving this set of equations requires a special tool. Many iterative algorithms are proposed to solve this set of equations. A detailed survey of the various computational efforts to solve optimal SOF problems is presented in Makila and Toivonen (1987). Most of these algorithms incline for local minimum points or are non-convergent. For that reason, in this paper a GA is proposed as a global search technique to solve equations (33)–(35).

sec.title: 4. Optimal SOF search using genetic algorithms
sec.p: Genetic algorithms are now considered one of the most popular optimization and search techniques (Omran et al., 2009; Omran and Kassem 2010). The first obvious application for the algorithm can be traced back to 1962, when Holland (1975) introduced the algorithm in his work studying adaptive systems. The algorithm then received an enormous exploration by Goldberg (2002). The main advantages of GA are its global optimization performance and the ease of distributing its calculations among several processors or computers as it operates on a population of solutions that can be evaluated concurrently. It is a very simple method, generally applicable, not inclined to local optimization problems that arise in a multimodal search space, andhas no need for special mathematical treatment. Moreover, the algorithm is more applicable to the discontinuous problem, as in the case of the present study, unlike the conventional gradient-based searching algorithms.

Basically, genetic algorithm works are based on the mechanism of natural selection and evolutionary genetics. The algorithm starts by coding the variables to binary strings (chromosomes). Every chromosome hasn genes. The gene is a binary bit with value zero or one. Three main operations control the procedure ofthe GA: reproduction, crossover, and mutation. Reproduction is a process to select the parent from a generation. The process is based on survival of the fittest (highest performance index). In this way, the reproduction process guides the search for best individuals (high performance index). After the individuals are selected, a crossover process is then used to swap between two chromosomes by specific probabilistic decision. The crossover process generates offspring carrying mixed information from swapped parents (chromosomes). Mutation is the mechanism that prevents the algorithm from local optimal points by adding some degree of randomness. The process is performed by alternation of the gene from zero to one or from one to zero with the mutation point determined uniformly at random. The mutation rate should be considered carefully, because higher mutation rate means that a higher number of generations is required for algorithm convergence and a low mutation rate may lead to convergence for local minimum. The algorithm maintains a constant size of generation by selecting the fittestchromosomes from parents and offsprings. Thealgorithm iteratively operates to converge for schema matches by some tolerance. Roughly, a genetic algorithm works as shown in Table 1. Further description of genetic algorithms can be found in Goldberg (2002). Table 1.
The pseudo-code of genetic algorithm
BEGIN GA
Make initial population at random.
WHILE NOT (stopping condition) DO
BEGIN
Select parents from the population.
Produce offspring from the selected
parents (crossover).
Mutate the individuals.
Extend the population adding the offspring to it.
Reduce the extended population.
END
Output the best individual found.
END GA

The algorithm listed in Table 1 is now used to solve equations (33)–(35). The step of this optimization is summarized as:
Generate an initial guessing of Ky. For efficiency of the algorithm, the steady gains of the transfer matrix of LQR lims→0[G]uy can be used as an initial value. The initial value should guarantee that the system is stable or all the poles of [A-BuKyC] are in the lefthand side. If the system is unstable for the generated Ky the cost function is set to be zero. In this case, a trial and error search is used to find the initial value.
Compute P from equation (34) and S from equation(35). Such solution requires rewriting the two equations as a set of linear equation of both Sij andPij.
Compute the estimated K~y from equation (33). The cost function is then defined as
(36)F=1ɛ+∑i=1Ny∑j=1Nu ||Ky(i,j)-K~y(i,j) ||2 where ɛ is an arbitrarily small value, which prevents generating any singularity. The pseudo code in Table 1 keep iterates to search for maximum F or minimum value between the estimated and actual matrix Ky.

sec.title: 5. Numerical simulations
sec.p:
The numerical values used are listed in Table 2. Table 2.
The numerical values used during simulation
Plate Cavity PZT Patch
Lxp =24 inch Lxc =24 inch Lxpzt =2 inch
Lyp =18 inch Lyc =18 inch Lypzt =1 inch
hp =0.0625 inch Lzc =20 inch hpzt =0.0125 inch
Ep =7.1 x 1010 N/m2 co =343 m/sec Epzt =10.5 x 106 N/m2
ρp =2700 kg/m3 ρo =1.21 kg/m3 d31 =−247 x 10−12 m/V
ν =0.3
ν =0.3

The natural frequencies of the clamped plate have been calculated by using the following approximate formula, which is based on an energy (Raleigh) technique (Blevins, 1979): (37)fij=π2Dρphp[Gi4Lxp4+Gj4Lyp4+2HiHjLxp2Lyp2]

Due to the complexity of the structural-acoustic coupling of this system, the effect of the stiffness coupling matrix Kpc and the inertia coupling matrix Mcp on the coupled natural frequencies cannot be easily realized. In Table 2, the entries of Mcp increase the values of thefirst few acoustic resonance frequencies above their uncoupled values, hence contributing a “mass reduction” effect. On the other hand, the entries of Kpc decrease the values of the low (vibration) resonance frequencies below their uncoupled values, hence contributing a “stiffness reduction” effect.

In the uncompensated and compensated systems, we will use 17 plate vibration modes (M) and three cavity acoustic modes (N). The structure acoustic model outputs are the displacements of the middle points of theupper and lower plates. Nine control actuators are assumed to be at the upper plate. The actuators are distributed in equal areas over the plates.

GA propagates are based on the algorithm previously listed in Section 4. The mutation rate is 10%. Each generation has a fixed population size of 100 orno generation overlap. The algorithm is convergentfor all techniques with 1000 generations. The resultant optimal controller gains based on GA are given as:

In order to judge the efficacy of using GA to search for the solution of equations (33)–(35), a simple comparison is given with the traditional simplex optimization technique, which is implemented in Matlab toolbox. This technique starts by creating a simplex of N + 1 points, where N is the optimized degree-of-freedom (k = 1,2,…,N) for the cost function in equation (36). These N + 1 points are arranged in descending order based on their equivalent cost functions. The points are then updated through their centroid point by four logics: reflecting, expanding, contracting, and shrinking. The simplex algorithm has been propagated from four different initial values. These four runs are convergent to error values as 11,727, 130,719, 11,893, and 8452 respectively, while the GA delivers a value 10.358 in just one run. However, applying the simplex algorithm repeatedly could reach a better solution, but there is no guarantee.

In equation (39), the controller at the operating condition listed in Table 2 is given. This control is a static one. At different operating conditions, other controller matrices could be computed following the same algorithm. The global controller is generated by tabulating the local controller with these flight conditions, while interpolation is employed to switch in between. On the other hand, the LQR delivers a controller with the same size; however each element is a transfer function of order 75th. Such a controller is computationally inefficient and virtually impossible to be applied to a gain scheduling approach. In fact, LQR provides a better performance than SOF, but the SOF still has an acceptable performance.

Using the previous analysis, numerical simulation is applied to the system. The objective in the simulation is to attenuate the vibration for the upper and lower plates. Figures 3 and 4 illustrate the resulting pressure response for damped sinusoidal pressure input. It isobserved that the maximum amplitude and the settling time are highly reduced and the response can be tuned to a certain value by adjusting the parameters used in the control model. Figure 3.
Uncompensated and compensated time responses of the middle point of the upper plate. The input is an impulse pressure input applied at the upper plate.
Figure 4.
Uncompensated and compensated time responses of the middle point of the lower plate. The input is an impulse pressure input applied at the upper plate.

An interesting investigation is to study how the SOF control space (possible solutions) would be affected by saturation limits and phase lag in the filtering system employed. In Section 2.2, the induced strain of the PZT patch is assumed to be linearly dependent on the input voltage. An experimental study by Al-Bassyiouni (2004), for the same numerical values, shows that the free-strain at the PZT surface is only linear in the range of ± 80 voltage. Otherwise, the linear assumption fails due to the significant nonlinearity embedded in the voltage-strain relationship. For this reason, the control action or the voltage passed to the PZT is bounded between ± 80 voltages. Different test cases were conducted at a higher impulse pressure amplitude as shown in Figures 5 and 6, because the control effort of the test case in Figures 3 and 4 doesn’t reach the actuation limits. It is clear that the PZT5 (located at the center of the upper plate) reaches the saturation before the others (see Figure 5) because the deflection at thecenter is expected to be the highest, leading to a high control action (voltage or induced strain). Because the control action is directly employed on the upper plate, the actuator’s saturation does not significantly affect the vibration of the upper plate, since the saturation period does not yield for a long time (see Figure 5). On the other hand, the saturation leads to an increase in the magnitude of the lower plate’s vibration as (see Figure 6). Figure 5.
Control voltage of static output feedback control with saturation.
Figure 6.
Displacement of lower plate for static output feedback with saturation.

Similar results for the influence of the saturation in the case of the LQR controller are shown in Figures 7 and 8. Since the LQR controller provides more damped response, the control efforts are expected to be higher than in the case of an SOF controller. Increasing the control effort in the case of the LQR increases the saturation time (see Figure 7) and it leads to unstable response after 2 seconds (see Figure 8). Figure 7.
Control voltage of linear quadratic regulator control without saturation.
Figure 8.
Displacement of lower plate for linear quadratic regulator control with saturation.

There is an induced phase delay from the acoustic wave propagation inside and outside the enclosure as well as the feedback controller and the electronics. These time delays might cause oscillations and instability to an otherwise stable equilibrium. Based on the numerical simulation, the SOF control is able to sustain a time delay up to 4 ms. On the other hand, the LQR control does not sustain a delay of any more than 0.5 ms. However, for both LQR and SOF controllers, a Pade approximation of these delays can be used to enhance the model-based controller. Figure 9 shows a test case for time delays of 2.5 ms (stable) and 8 ms (unstable). Figure 10 shows the control voltage in the case of a 2.5 ms time delay. For a more realistic simulation, a generic noise model is added to the simulation of the cases shown in Figures 9 and 10 taking into consideration the saturation limits. Figure 9.
Displacement of upper plate for static output feedback control with noise, saturation, and delay time.
Figure 10.
Control voltage of static output feedback control with noise, saturation, and delay time 2.5 s.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: In this work, the development of a static output feedback controller for a structure-acoustics coupled system based on genetic-optimization is studied. Modeling of sound transmission through a plate-cavity-plate system is presented. The system consists of a rectangular cavity with two flexible plates, one at the top of the cavity and the other at the bottom, and four other rigid boundaries. The proposed controller is used in damping the vibration of the plates. In the control scheme, the procedure offers a controller for practical utilization. The technique was successfully applied to one operating point. The proposed controller is a static matrix with more applicability to be scheduled. This information is unobtainable from other control methods such as a linear quadratic regulator. The interpolated is used to extend across the flight envelope. Also, the performance of the controller is compared to the linear quadratic regulator. Based on the numerical simulations, the LQR technique has the ability to dampen the vibration more than the proposed static output feedback. Such results were predicted because the LQR assumes moreavailable information than the SOF. Although the linear quadratic regulator shows better performance, the static feedback offers a more practical controller. The controller is a trade-off between feasibility and performance.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
